content.question:
Given the following information, calculate the lift coefficient for an aircraft in straight and level flight, flying in a clean configuration just above the clean stall speed.
Density: 1.225 kg/m³
TAS: 73 kt
Mass: 7 300 kg
Wing area: 49 m2
G: 9.81 m/s2

key_points: This question requires use of the lift formula
Lift = 1/2 x ρ x V2 x CL x S Where; ρ = Air Density, V = Velocity (true air speed), CL = Coefficient of Lift, S = Wing Area
To use the formula above, we need everything in the correct units
learning.explanation: This question requires use of the lift formula. Lift = 1/2 x ρ x V2 x CL x S Where; ρ = Air Density, V = Velocity (true air speed), CL = Coefficient of Lift, S = Wing Area. To use the formula above, we need everything in the correct units. That means that we have to convert the velocity (TAS) from knots into m/s. As 1 knot is one nautical mile per hour, we have to multiply by the amount of metres in a nautical mile (1852) and then divide by the amount of seconds in an hour (3600). Velocity = 73 kt x 1852/3600 = 37.55 m/s We are going to rearrange the formula to find the CL, and that means we need to have a value for the lift produced by the wing. As we are in straight and level flight, Lift = Weight, so we just need the weight of the aircraft. Weight = Mass x Acceleration due to gravity (G). Therefore; Lift = Weight = 7300 x 9.81 = 71613 N Referring to the rearranged equation in the annex above; CL = (2 x 71613) / (1.225 x (37.55)2 x 49) = 1.69

content.question: In order to keep straight and level, if the airspeed increases, the EAF is (1) _____, the effective AoA is (2) ______ and the induced drag is (3) ______.

options.A: (1) shallower, (2) greater, (3) smaller
options.B: (1) steeper, (2) greater, (3) greater
options.C: (1) shallower, (2) smaller, (3) smaller
options.D: (1) shallower, (2) greater, (3) greater

key_points: The purpose of this question is to combine two different items from the Learning Objectives

The first is to use the lift formula: LIFT = ½ x ρ x V2 x S x CL and determine that in order to keep straight and level flight (L=W), an increase in speed must be balanced with a decrease in CL, which is achieved by decreasing the angle of attack
The other part is to establish a relationship between induced drag and speed
learning.explanation: The purpose of this question is to combine two different items from the Learning Objectives. The first is to use the lift formula: LIFT = ½ x ρ x V2 x S x CL and determine that in order to keep straight and level flight (L=W), an increase in speed must be balanced with a decrease in CL, which is achieved by decreasing the angle of attack. The other part is to establish a relationship between induced drag and speed. From the graph attached to this explanation, we can conclude that an increase in speed leads to an decrease in induced drag. If you refer to the second attached figure, we can conclude how the Effective Airflow, Effective Angle of Attack, and Induced Drag behave: Wing tip vortices create certain vertical velocity components in the airflow in the vicinity of the wing, both in front of and behind it. These vertical velocities strengthen upwash and downwash, which reduce the effective angle of attack. The stronger the vortices, the greater the reduction in effective angle of attack. The effective angle of attack is the actual or effective angle of attack at the aerofoil. In level flight at a given mass the lift generated is the same at all forward speeds above the stalling speed. Because the angle of attack must decrease with increasing speed the same downwash speed has less effect at a high speed than it does at a low forward speed because it has a smaller downwash vector. Thus, the downwash angle is less at higher speeds than it is at lower forward speeds. Therefore, the induced drag is decreased at high speeds.

learning.explanation: This is a graph of CL (Coefficient of Lift) versus α (alpha - Angle of Attack). It shows us what coefficient of lift is given at each angle of attack of a particular wing. The bottom of the graph, on the left, is where the angle of attack is low. In terms of level flight, this is where the aircraft must be flying fast in order to maintain the same lift force (equal to weight). Therefore, the top right of the graph is high angles of attack, including the stall. Therefore, going from A to B on the graph includes increasing the angle of attack (thereby increasing the coefficient of lift). This is what we do when we slow down, as with less airflow over the wings, we need each individual air particle to provide more lift in order to counteract weight. Therefore, the answer is that we must slow down to keep a constant lift, as if we did not slow down, the aircraft would have too much lift when we go from point A to point B and would start pulling upwards.

content.question:
Which statements about an aeroplane leaving ground effect are correct or incorrect?
1) The downwash angle increases.
2) The induced angle of attack increases.

options.A: 1) is correct, 2) is incorrect.
options.B: 1) is incorrect, 2) is incorrect.
options.C: 1) is correct, 2) is correct.
options.D: 1) is incorrect, 2) is correct.

key_points: When an airplane flies at a height equal to or less than the length of its wingspan the efficiency of its wings is considerably improved
A low wing airplane, just before touchdown, experiences a 50% reduction of its total drag
This phenomenon is ground effect
learning.explanation: When an airplane flies at a height equal to or less than the length of its wingspan the efficiency of its wings is considerably improved. A low wing airplane, just before touchdown, experiences a 50% reduction of its total drag. This phenomenon is ground effect. Ground effect occurs because the surface alters the airflow pattern around the wings. Primarily, the surface restricts the formation of the wingtip vortices. When an aircraft enters ground effect during the landing phase of flight, the sudden increase in lift and reduction in drag cause it to experience a floating tendency. The aircraft also tends to pitch nose-down due to the reduction in download on the tail plane. The magnitude of the wing tip vortices, and thus downwash, also determine the amount of induced drag produced by the wing. The closer the aircraft is to the surface, the greater the reduction in induced drag at any given angle of attack. Aircraft entering ground effect: Downwash decreases. The effective angle of attack increases. Increased lift during landing if the angle of attack remains constant. The induced angle of attack decreases. Induced drag decreases. Aircraft leaving ground effect: The effective angle of attack decreases. Decreased lift during take-off if the angle of attack remains constant. Induced drag increases. Downwash increases. Therefore, statement 1 is correct. The induced angle of attack increases. Therefore, statement 2 is correct.

content.question: While performing the “After Engine Start” procedures, the pilots of a commercial jet aircraft forget to set the slats/flaps in the calculated take-off position. What could be a consequence of this action?

options.A: A safe to take-off will be possible as this case is considered in the VR calculation.
options.B: After rotation, the aircraft will stall after getting airborne.
options.C: There would be insufficient elevator authority such that the aeroplane will NOT rotate.
options.D: Acceleration will be lower, but a safe take-off will be conducted.

key_points: Take-off with lower-than-calculated flap position leads to several possible incidents, since the real stall speed will be higher than the calculated one
If the pilots happen to think that the flaps are lowered for take-off and they calculated their rotation speed taking the flaps into consideration, then it is an issue
With the flaps, the rotation speed will be lower than that without and the premature take-off will result in a stall
learning.explanation: Take-off with lower-than-calculated flap position leads to several possible incidents, since the real stall speed will be higher than the calculated one. If the pilots happen to think that the flaps are lowered for take-off and they calculated their rotation speed taking the flaps into consideration, then it is an issue. With the flaps, the rotation speed will be lower than that without and the premature take-off will result in a stall. Flaps give more lift at a given speed, hence with flaps the rotation is speed is lower. There is also risk of tail strike, where the rotation is started before is it possible at lift-off, consequently angle of attack might be increased up to tailstrike.

content.question: You are flying at a constant CAS in the unstable speed region and encounter a wind shear which changes a headwind into a tailwind. What will happen?

options.A: Nothing will happen, but should fly carefully from this point and forward
options.B: Airspeed will decrease because the total drag is more
options.C: Airspeed will increases because the total drag is less
options.D: The aeroplane will stall due to insufficient lift

key_points: During flight, an aircraft will experience Parasite Drag (proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing “Parasite Area” => flaps, undercarriage or speed brakes) and Induced Drag (inversely proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing weight)
The sum of Parasite Drag and Induced Drag is the Total Drag
The Total Drag will be minimum at the IAS where Parasite Drag = Induced Drag
learning.explanation: During flight, an aircraft will experience Parasite Drag (proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing “Parasite Area” => flaps, undercarriage or speed brakes) and Induced Drag (inversely proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing weight). The sum of Parasite Drag and Induced Drag is the Total Drag. The Total Drag will be minimum at the IAS where Parasite Drag = Induced Drag. This speed is called Minimum Drag Speed (VMD); => Flying at a slower or faster speed than VMD will generate more drag. When flying at a slower speed than VMD (back side), the aircraft will be in the unstable speed region. Any loss of speed will result in an increase in drag and further speed loss (which must be corrected by an increase in thrust). The sudden change to a tailwind will cause a loss of airspeed.

Assuming all bodies have the same cross-sectional area and are in motion, place these bodies in order of increasing pressure drag.The correct answer is:

key_points: Total Drag is sub-divided into two main types: Parasite Drag - independent of lift generation, and Induced Drag - the result of lift generation
Parasite drag is further sub-divided into: Skin Friction Drag Form (Pressure) Drag, and Interference Drag NOTE: Skin Friction and Form Drag are together known as PROFILE DRAG
Form drag is produced whenever the streamline airflow passing over an aircraft separates from the surface and becomes turbulent
learning.explanation: Total Drag is sub-divided into two main types: Parasite Drag - independent of lift generation, and Induced Drag - the result of lift generation. Parasite drag is further sub-divided into: Skin Friction Drag Form (Pressure) Drag, and Interference Drag NOTE: Skin Friction and Form Drag are together known as PROFILE DRAG. Form drag is produced whenever the streamline airflow passing over an aircraft separates from the surface and becomes turbulent. An example of extreme form drag is the effect of a flat plate placed at right angles to the airflow. The pressure immediately in front of the plate is above atmospheric, whilst the pressure behind the plate is below atmospheric. This results in a sucking effect behind the plate and the formation of vortices. The more rapidly the airflow changes direction, the greater the pressure gradient, the earlier the separation, and the higher the form drag. Changing the shape, or streamline, of a given object reduces drag by delaying the point at which the airflow separates.

content.question:
Which of these statements about the strength of wing tip vortices are correct or incorrect
I. Assuming no flow separation, the strength of wing tip vortices is not affected by angle of attack.
II. The strength of wing tip vortices is not affected by aspect ratio.

options.A: I is correct, II is incorrect.
options.B: I is correct, II is correct.
options.C: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
options.D: I is incorrect, II is correct.

key_points: Wing tip vortices are a byproduct of lift
They are caused by the pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing, which causes an updraft of high pressure air around the tip of the wing
This updraft turn into a downdraft behind the wing, creating a vortex
learning.explanation: Wing tip vortices are a byproduct of lift. They are caused by the pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing, which causes an updraft of high pressure air around the tip of the wing. This updraft turn into a downdraft behind the wing, creating a vortex. The higher the pressure difference between the top and bottom of the wing, the stronger the vortices. This question is specifically asking for: Angle of attack: The strength of the vortices (and therefore also induced drag) is proportional to the angle of attack. Therefore; the strength of the vortices increase as the angle of attack increases. And also; the strength of the vortices decrease as the angle of attack decreases. Therefore statement 1 is incorrect! Aspect ratio: The strength of the vortices is inversely proportional with the aspect ratio. Meaning that the strength of the wing tip vortices increase as the aspect ratio decreases. And vice versa: the strength decreases as the aspect ratio increases. Therefore statement 2 is incorrect!

content.question: Whilst maintaining straight and level flight with a lift coefficient CL = 1 what will be the new approximate value of CL after the speed is increased by 30%?

key_points: Lift can be calculated as follows: L= CL × ½ rho × V2 × S Where: CL is lift coefficient (without dimension) p is density V is velocity [m/s] (velocity is TAS) S is surface area [m2] L is lift [N] ⇒ If the velocity increases by 30%, lift increases by 1
learning.explanation: Lift can be calculated as follows: L= CL × ½ rho × V2 × S Where: CL is lift coefficient (without dimension) p is density V is velocity [m/s] (velocity is TAS) S is surface area [m2] L is lift [N] ⇒ If the velocity increases by 30%, lift increases by 1.302 = 1.69 (69%). To maintain lift constant (straight and level flight), lift coefficient (CL) must be 0.60 of the old CL (x 0.60): 1 ÷ 1.69.

content.question: The highest value of the CL/CD ratio of an aeroplane is obtained:

options.A: in the configuration where both the leading and trailing edge flaps are fully extended.
options.B: in the configuration where only the trailing edge flaps are fully extended.
options.C: in the clean configuration.
options.D: in the configuration where only the leading edge slats are fully extended.

key_points: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together
Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air
It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag
learning.explanation: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together. Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air. It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag. Form drag arises from the shape of the object. The more streamlined the object, the less form drag is present. Shape and size are most important in the amount of form drag resulting. Form drag increases with increasing velocity, making it very important for high speed aircraft. Skin friction drag is caused by the friction of the fluid (in case of aircraft this fluid is the atmosphere) against the skin of the object moving through it. It is directly related to the surface area in contact with the fluid. Skin friction increases with the square of the velocity. Induced drag is caused when an object redirects the airflow. A wing produces lift by creating a pressure difference. This pressure difference is caused by the shape of the airfoil, causing the airflow on top to accelerate, creating a low pressure on top of the wing and high pressure below the wing. This pressure difference naturally wants to restore towards a uniform pressure, which creates vortices around the wingtip. These vortices are deflected downwards, this phenomenon is also called downwash. The induced drag decreases with airspeed and increases with angle of attack and increasing weight. In the image we can see that the two vectors (induced and parasite drag) create a resulting vector, the total drag. Where the induced and parasite drag vectors collide, we have the minimum drag speed (VMD); the speed where the total drag is the lowest. This leads us to understand that during an acceleration from a total stand still, the total drag first decreases up until the minimum drag speed and then starts increasing again. The CL/CD ratio is therefore biggest at VMD. Adding flaps or slats to this configuration will generate a large amount of drag, worsening the ratio. Therefore the highest value of the CL/CD ratio is obtained in clean configuration at VMD.

content.question: Ground effect has the following influence on the landing distance:

options.A: increases, only if the landing flaps are fully extended.
options.B: does not change.
options.C: increases.
options.D: decreases.

key_points: Ground effect occurs because the surface alters the airflow pattern around the wings
Primarily, the surface restricts the formation of the wingtip vortices
This results in a reduction in the amount of induced downwash behind the wing and increases the wing’s effective angle of attack
learning.explanation: Ground effect occurs because the surface alters the airflow pattern around the wings. Primarily, the surface restricts the formation of the wingtip vortices. This results in a reduction in the amount of induced downwash behind the wing and increases the wing’s effective angle of attack. It also alters the pressure distribution around the wing and the amount of lift developed. This occurs because the change in effective angle of attack increases the wing’s coefficient of lift (CL) and thus its lifting capability at any given angle of attack. The magnitude of the wing tip vortices, and thus downwash, also determine the amount of induced drag produced by the wing. The closer the aircraft is to the surface, the greater the reduction in induced drag at any given angle of attack. (figure 2) THE INFLUENCE OF GROUND EFFECT ON LANDING When an aircraft enters ground effect during the landing phase of flight, the sudden increase in lift and reduction in drag cause it to experience a floating tendency. The aircraft also tends to pitch nose-down due to the reduction in download on the tailplane.

Which type of flap re-energises the boundary layer?

options.A: 1. Plain Flap
options.B: 2. Slotted Flap
options.C: 3. Split Flap
options.D: 4. Fowler Flap

key_points: The question figure shows 4 types of flaps: Plain flap -The standard for many light aircraft, increases available lift and increases drag
Easy to manufacture Slotted flap - Increases maximum lift by more than plain flaps, due to the slots allowing high velocity air through to re-energise the boundary layers, preventing separation
Increases drag also over plain flaps
learning.explanation: The question figure shows 4 types of flaps: Plain flap -The standard for many light aircraft, increases available lift and increases drag. Easy to manufacture Slotted flap - Increases maximum lift by more than plain flaps, due to the slots allowing high velocity air through to re-energise the boundary layers, preventing separation. Increases drag also over plain flaps. Used commonly on large jet aircraft for slow flight and landing (sometimes in conjunction with the fowler flaps below). Split flap - Increases drag heavily due to the open trailing edge. Very easy to manufacture. Fowler flap - Complex to design and fit, but increase lift by a large amount due to the increased wing area and camber. Increase in drag over plain flaps is smaller than the increased lift, so they provide a high L/D ratio, and are often used in conjunction with multiple levels of slotted flaps on larger aircraft.

The dotted line represents how a lift curve changes when a high-lift device is deployed. To which of these devices could the curve apply to?

key_points: Aircraft are fitted with high lift devices to reduce the take-off and landing distances and improve slow flying characteristics

The three leading edge devices shown in the annex are: Leading Edge Flaps - similar to trailing edge flaps, they increase the camber of the wing to increase CL and CLMAX Krueger Flaps - part of the lower surface of the leading edge, which can be rotated about its forward edge to force more airflow over the top of the wing at high angles of attack
The graph for krueger flaps is not quite a simple as but for this question it is fine to use
learning.explanation: Aircraft are fitted with high lift devices to reduce the take-off and landing distances and improve slow flying characteristics. The three leading edge devices shown in the annex are: Leading Edge Flaps - similar to trailing edge flaps, they increase the camber of the wing to increase CL and CLMAX Krueger Flaps - part of the lower surface of the leading edge, which can be rotated about its forward edge to force more airflow over the top of the wing at high angles of attack. The graph for krueger flaps is not quite a simple as but for this question it is fine to use. Slats - These are small "extra leading edges" that move forward in front of the leading edge of the wing, creating a small slot behind, where airflow is sped up and re-energised, delaying the stalling angle of attack without increasing the CL at normal angles of attack. Kreuger Flaps and Slats are often used in conjunction, with Kreuger Flaps being used on the inboard section of an wing and slats being used outboard of the engine pylons, to promote root stall tendency due to the Kreuger Flaps being less effective. For this question, the slats are the only leading edge device that fit the graph perfectly, and this is a very common high-lift device to use in questions, due to the distinctive CL vs AoA graph, so be familiar with it. "Fowler Flap" Incorrect. These are Trailing Edge devices. They change the graph in a different way to leading edge devices, and fowler flaps even moreso.

content.question: Consider an aircraft flying in unaccelerated level flight in the speed stable region. What would be the result on the drag following a sudden increase in aircraft speed with no change in thrust available?

key_points: During flight, an aircraft will experience two types of drag: - Parasite Drag (proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing “Parasite Area”: flaps, undercarriage or speedbrakes) - Induced Drag (inversely proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing weight)
The sum of Parasite Drag and Induced Drag is the Total Drag
The Total Drag will be minimum at the IAS where Parasite Drag = Induced Drag
learning.explanation: During flight, an aircraft will experience two types of drag: - Parasite Drag (proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing “Parasite Area”: flaps, undercarriage or speedbrakes) - Induced Drag (inversely proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing weight). The sum of Parasite Drag and Induced Drag is the Total Drag. The Total Drag will be minimum at the IAS where Parasite Drag = Induced Drag. This speed is called Minimum Drag Speed (VMD). Flying at a slower or faster speed than VMD will generate more drag. Flying at a slower speed than VMD (back side), the aircraft will be in the unstable speed region. Any gain of speed will result in an decrease in drag and further speed increase. The sudden change to a headwind (or a decrease in tailwind) can cause a gain of airspeed. Flying at a faster speed than VMD (front side), the aircraft will be in the stable speed region. Any increase of speed will result in an increase in drag. This increase in drag will cause the speed to decrease again (unless the thrust has changed). Therefore, a sudden increase in headwind (or a decrease in tailwind) can cause a momentary increase of airspeed, which eventually settles back to the original airspeed.

Learning Objective 081.01.04.02.01: Describe the general streamline pattern around the wing, tail section, and fuselage. Learning Objective 081.01.04.02.02: Explain and describe the causes of spanwise flow over top and bottom surfaces. The streamlines of air around an aeroplane just depict the path that air particles take past the aircraft in flight, so primarily front to back, and they have to move out of the way of the aircraft's fuselage, wings, tail fin, engine nacelles, etc. Any time streamlines converge (come together), the air accelerates and the static pressure drops, and any time they diverge (get further apart), the airspeed drops and the static pressure rises, which brings about pressure distributions, lift and drag forces on the aircraft. 2 dimensional streamlines around the wing cross-section are shown in the first image above, but this question is certainly asking about 3 dimensional airflow, and that gets more complicated. The main area of 3D airflow is spanwise flow over the wings and wingtip vortices, which are effectively the same thing. Because wings are not infinitely long, there has to be a wingtip somewhere, and high pressure air from under the wing can cheat the system by going round the tip and getting to the upper wing surface. as streamlines of air affect the other nearby streamlines, this means that the air under the wing has a "spanwise" flow outwards, and the air on top of the wing has a spanwise flow inwards. When these two flows meet at the rear of the wing, they swirl around each other, causing vortices, strongest at the wingtip and getting weaker towards the wing root. This creates a familiar wingtip vortex area as shown above. Now for the answers. None of them are very good so we have chosen the best in our opinion as the correct one. "The streamlines typically follow the direction of the lateral axis of the aeroplane and remain attached along the entire length of the aeroplane." Definitely incorrect. The lateral axis goes from left to right, and the streamlines go from front to back. "The streamlines typically follow the contours of the fuselage, but they will have a slight spanwise flow producing a lift-like force." Likely incorrect. They do indeed follow the contours of the fuselage, but "spanwise flow" means from left to right, because it is along the wingspan, and this doesn't really hold true for fuselage airflow, and doesn't really produce any such lift-like force that we can think of. "On the entire aft section of the fuselage, the streamlines typically follow the corkscrew pattern of the wing tip vortices." Maybe incorrect. This one depends on the wording, but worded like this, we would say it is incorrect. A corkscrew pattern around the entire aft section of the fuselage sounds like what happens behind a nose-mounted propeller, but that wasn't specified in the question. Wingtip vortices (which we suspect are the purpose of the question) cause two vortices, spiralling in opposite directions, and stray far from the aft fuselage. "Across the entire wingspan of the main wings, the streamlines typically follow the corkscrew pattern of the wing tip vortices." Best answer here. The 3 dimensional flow around the wings does make somewhat of a corkscrew pattern, and it is completely because of the wingtip vortex for that wing. The spanwise component of the flow is much greater near the wingtip and very little near the wing root, but it is still there nonetheless, and after the wing becomes very much "corkscrew-like".

learning.explanation: In icing conditions, pilots have to be very careful. Not only does ice accretion add weight and drag to an aircraft, it also changes the shape of the wing, reducing the finely tuned lift characteristics. In particular, clear ice is very bad, as the accretion does not all happen on the leading edge of the wing, but drips backwards over the wing surface, freezing continuously as it goes. This is the "flow back" ice that one of the correct statements mentions. It covers over the aerofoil and changes the shape, sometimes quite dramatically. This will decrease the critical angle of attack, and therefore the stalling speed in level flight will increase. Icing of the pitot and static ports is also a problem when dealing with icing conditions. This is why pitot and static probes are heated, to avoid any such issues. If they do become iced over, the pilots may find it difficult to know what airspeed they are flying at, and therefore may be unsure of their angle of attack, which can lead to an unexpected stall.

key_points: Lift = 1/2 x ρ x V2 x CL x S Where: ρ is the air density V is the TAS (True Airspeed) CL is the Coefficient of lift S is the wing area Using the lift above, we can see that if an aircraft reduces in speed (V2 reduces), then the lift will decrease, unless one of the other components increases to cover the loss
In this case, the pilot has added a stage of flaps, which will increase the lift coefficient by increasing the camber of the wing

The point of this question is not really to know that the flaps increase the camber, and therefore increase the available lift coefficient, but to know that the aircraft slowing down will require a higher coefficient of lift to maintain enough lift to overcome weight, therefore allowing it to maintain altitude
learning.explanation: Lift = 1/2 x ρ x V2 x CL x S Where: ρ is the air density V is the TAS (True Airspeed) CL is the Coefficient of lift S is the wing area Using the lift above, we can see that if an aircraft reduces in speed (V2 reduces), then the lift will decrease, unless one of the other components increases to cover the loss. In this case, the pilot has added a stage of flaps, which will increase the lift coefficient by increasing the camber of the wing. The point of this question is not really to know that the flaps increase the camber, and therefore increase the available lift coefficient, but to know that the aircraft slowing down will require a higher coefficient of lift to maintain enough lift to overcome weight, therefore allowing it to maintain altitude. The same increase of CL could have been made by increasing the angle of attack, but this might have brought the aircraft close to or past the stalling angle of attack, so flaps might be the best choice. Some may wonder why answer A, "The new CL is greater than 0.38 because flaps always increase the CL.", is not correct. It is because flaps do not always increase the CL. If we remain at the same AoA and add flaps, the CL will almost always increase, but this is rarely what we do. If we added flaps but remained at the same speed, and at the same altitude, the CL would stay the same, as none of the components in the Lift equation would have changed. We would then be flying at a lower angle of attack, though, and with higher drag.

content.question: What happens to a wing's critical angle of attack when it enters ground effect?

options.A: Decreases
options.B: Increases
options.C: Remains unchanged
options.D: Increase then decreases

key_points: GROUND EFFECT When an aeroplane flies at a height equal to or less than the length of its wingspan the efficiency of its wings is considerably improved
A low-wing aeroplane, just before touchdown, experiences a 50% reduction of its total drag
This phenomenon is ground effect, which is only experienced for conventional aeroplanes during the initial climb phase after take-off and the final descent phase during landing
learning.explanation: GROUND EFFECT When an aeroplane flies at a height equal to or less than the length of its wingspan the efficiency of its wings is considerably improved. A low-wing aeroplane, just before touchdown, experiences a 50% reduction of its total drag. This phenomenon is ground effect, which is only experienced for conventional aeroplanes during the initial climb phase after take-off and the final descent phase during landing. At low airspeeds it is considered that the air is non compressible and, because of the close proximity of the earth’s surface, the upwash of air ahead of the wing is reduced. Thus, because of the diminished negative lift, the downwash over the upper surface of the wing does not have to be as large as it would be normally. This enables the aeroplane to maintain level flight at a lower than usual angle of attack, which decreases the induced drag and improves the efficiency of the wing. The consequences of operating in ground effect at a constant IAS are: - Decreased upwash and downwash angles produce smaller wing-tip vortices. - Increased Cl. - Significantly decreased induced drag coefficient; by approximately 8% at a height equal to half wingspan and reduced by considerably more at any lower height. - Decreased total drag (no effect on parasite drag). - Decreased angle of attack for a given lift coefficient. - Increased angle of attack for a constant IAS. - Decreased stalling angle of attack. - Decreased induced angle of attack. - Increased lift, if the pitch attitude remains constant. - Increased speed for a constant thrust setting. - Increased float distance on landing, if the angle of attack is constant, increasing the total landing distance. - The lift vector is inclined forward, which decreases the thrust required. - Less thrust and power are required to fly at the same speed.

content.question: Which of the following are means to reduce induced drag?

options.A: Increasing the wing thickness, camber, and span.
options.B: Decreasing the taper ratio, increasing the root chord and sweep angle.
options.C: Increasing the aspect ratio and wing twist, adding winglets.
options.D: Decreasing the wingspan, increasing the approach speed and take-off weight.

key_points: Whenever a wing produces lift, concentrated vortices form at the wing tips
The vortices are strongest at the wing tips and become progressively weaker toward the centerline of the aircraft
The vortices induce downwash to the airflow behind the wing, causing the lift vector to tilt rearward
learning.explanation: Whenever a wing produces lift, concentrated vortices form at the wing tips. The vortices are strongest at the wing tips and become progressively weaker toward the centerline of the aircraft. The vortices induce downwash to the airflow behind the wing, causing the lift vector to tilt rearward. The horizontal component of lift opposes the forward flight of the aircraft and is known as induced drag. The larger the vortex, the greater the induced downwash, and the greater the induced drag. It is advantageous to reduce induced drag to a minimum, and this is achieved using the following design features to minimize the formation of wing tip vortices: Tapering the wing in planform toward the tip reduces the amount of air flowing from the lower surface to the upper surface, thereby reducing the size of the wing tip vortex. Washout means constructing the wing with a small amount of twist from root to tip, so that the inboard wing section is at a higher angle of incidence, and hence a greater angle of attack, compared to the wing tip. This ensures that the inner part of the wing generates most of the lift, thus minimizing the leakage of airflow around the wing tips. This reduces the size of the wing tip vortex and reduces the total amount of induced drag. Wing tip modifications reduce the leakage of airflow around the wing tip and limit the size of the vortex. Some of the more typical designs include winglets, wing tip fence and wing tip tank.

content.question:
Which of these statements about the strength of wing tip vortices are correct or incorrect?
I. Assuming no flow separation, the strength of wing tip vortices increases as the angle of attack decreases.
II. The strength of wing tip vortices decreases as the aspect ratio decreases.

options.A: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.B: I is correct, II is incorrect.
options.C: I is correct, II is correct.
options.D: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.

key_points: Wing tip vortices increase if we increase induced drag
This can be caused by for example increased speed, density or lift coefficient
If we decrease Angle of Attack, lift will be decreased, also decreasing the strength of wing tip vortices
learning.explanation: Wing tip vortices increase if we increase induced drag. This can be caused by for example increased speed, density or lift coefficient. If we decrease Angle of Attack, lift will be decreased, also decreasing the strength of wing tip vortices. This shows that statement I is incorrect. Another factor increasing wing tip vortices is the aspect ratio (λ) of the wing. This is the ratio of the wing span to its mean chord. The aspect ratio of the wing is equal to the square od the wingspan divided by the wing surface area. Therefore a short but wide wing has a low aspect ratio but a long, narrow wing has a high aspect ratio. With a lower aspect ratio, the induced drag is higher, thus increasing wing tip vortices. With a high aspect ratio, the induced drag is lower, reducing wing tip vortices. We can therefore state that the relationship between wing tip vortices and aspect ratio is inversely proportional. Statement number II is incorrect, as the correct answer would be “The strength of wing tip vortices increases as the aspect ratio decreases.

key_points: In flight an aeroplane is subject to four types of four forces

The four forces are weight acting vertically downward, drag opposing the forward movement of the aeroplane acting parallel to the relative airflow, thrust acting in a forward direction and lift the upward force acting vertical to the relative airflow that enables the aeroplane to remain airborne
These forces must be in equilibrium during flight
learning.explanation: In flight an aeroplane is subject to four types of four forces. The four forces are weight acting vertically downward, drag opposing the forward movement of the aeroplane acting parallel to the relative airflow, thrust acting in a forward direction and lift the upward force acting vertical to the relative airflow that enables the aeroplane to remain airborne. These forces must be in equilibrium during flight. Lift must balance weight and thrust must balance drag. These forces are Lift is defined by: L = 1/2 x ρ x V2 x S x CL For a given wing area (S), if the altitude (i.e. air density) and mass remain constant then the remaining factors in the formula, the coefficient of lift (CL) and the free air velocity (IAS), are variable but have a fixed relationship. CL and IAS must change in such a manner that the total lift formula remains balanced. Lift coefficient increases with angle of attack up to a maximum (CLMAX), which corresponds to the “Critical” angle of attack. Continuing to increase the angle of attack beyond this point makes it impossible for the airflow to maintain its previous smooth flow over the contour of the upper surface, and lift will reduce. key_points: Wing tip vortices increase if we increase induced drag
This can be caused by for example increased speed, density or lift coefficient
If we increase Angle of Attack, lift will be increased, also increasing the strength of wing tip vortices
learning.explanation: Wing tip vortices increase if we increase induced drag. This can be caused by for example increased speed, density or lift coefficient. If we increase Angle of Attack, lift will be increased, also increasing the strength of wing tip vortices. Another factor increasing wing tip vortices is the aspect ratio (λ) of the wing. This is the ratio of the wing span to its mean chord. The aspect ratio of the wing is equal to the square of the wingspan divided by the wing surface area. Therefore a short but wide wing has a low aspect ratio but a long, narrow wing has a high aspect ratio. With a lower aspect ratio, the induced drag is higher, thus increasing wing tip vortices. With a high aspect ratio, the induced drag is lower, reducing wing tip vortices. We can therefore state that the relationship between wing tip vortices and aspect ratio is inversely proportional. A wing with a higher aspect ratio has a lower value for CLmax and will have a higher value of CL for a certain angle of attack.

key_points: To understand the venturi effect, we must first introduce two conditions: The conservation of mass (Continuity Equation) and the Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem)
Conservation of Mass (Continuity Equation) The mass of air entering the pipe, in each unit of time, equals the mass of air leaving the pipe, in the same unit of time
The mass flow through the pipe must remain constant
learning.explanation: To understand the venturi effect, we must first introduce two conditions: The conservation of mass (Continuity Equation) and the Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem). Conservation of Mass (Continuity Equation) The mass of air entering the pipe, in each unit of time, equals the mass of air leaving the pipe, in the same unit of time. The mass flow through the pipe must remain constant. The mass air flow 'm' is the product of the density, the area and the velocity: m = ρ * A * V Continuity equation: m1 = m2 = m3 = ρ1 * A1 * V1 = ρ2 * A2 * V2 = ρ3 * A3 * V3 = constant The continuity equation explains the relationship between velocity and cross-sectional area: The speed is inversely proportional to the cross-sectional area. Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem) The total energy of an airstream comes in two forms: potential energy (static pressure) and kinetic energy (dynamic pressure). The total pressure of the airstream is the sum of the static pressure and the dynamic pressure and must remain constant, according to the law of conservation of energy. Thus, an increase in one form of pressure, must result in a decrease in the other. Dynamic pressure (q) is expressed by: q = 1 / 2 * ρ * V2 Assuming the total pressure to be constant, the static pressure and the dynamic pressure vary inversely: If one increases the other decreases and vice-versa. In Conclusion: With a decrease in section area (from station 1 to station 2), flow speed increases, increasing dynamic pressure. Statement 1 is therefore incorrect. The total pressure of the airstream is the sum of the static pressure and the dynamic pressure and must remain constant, according to the law of conservation of energy. Statement 2 is therefore incorrect.

key_points: Spoilers are aerodynamic surfaces that exist on the top surface of some wings, and are used for many reasons
They are primarily used to increase drag and "dump" lift
(If they are just for drag then they are called speedbrakes, but aircraft manufacturers do blur these distinctions)
learning.explanation: Spoilers are aerodynamic surfaces that exist on the top surface of some wings, and are used for many reasons. They are primarily used to increase drag and "dump" lift. (If they are just for drag then they are called speedbrakes, but aircraft manufacturers do blur these distinctions). They are called spoilers because they "spoil" the airflow, sticking up into the airflow, causing a lift reduction similar to an up-going aileron and a similar drag increase to that of a split flap. Of course, the spoiled airflow is not as effective at producing lift, and the CLMAX of wings with spoilers extended is much lower, so the stall speed therefore increases. The effect on the critical angle of attack is much more complicated, however, and is not always easy to predict. As the spoiler pushes up into the airflow, the adverse pressure gradient over it (which usually causes the stall) is reduced and the airflow is re-energised, but the area behind the spoiler (most do not go all the way to the trailing edge of the wing) is automatically stalled after a small spoiler deflection, due to the gap created. So there are two opposing forces at play: Spoilers act a little bit like an up-going aileron, re-energising the airflow and increasing the critical AoA, The large stalled area behind the spoiler decreases the lift of the wing greatly, with an unknown effect on the critical AoA. Therefore, it is difficult to say what effect spoiler deflection will have on the critical AoA. Some sources mention a slight decrease in critical AoA overall, but it appears that EASA have published other questions where the overall effect is an increase in the critical AoA due to spoiler extension, so we have stuck with this across all questions, as it seems likely that the examiner wants this answer (and feedback has agreed with this in the past). Of course, the real answer is certain to depend on the proportion of the wing, the size and location of the spoiler, and most importantly, the amount of spoiler deflection. As this is so complex, the examiner’s choice of answer is all that truly matters here. We have therefore based this answer on feedback and other questions such as 819930 and 815643, but recent feedback is scarce, so please let us know if this is different if you see it in the real exam, thank you!

Thank you! The effect of flaps on Take-off Distance (TOD) is as follows: Initially, increasing flap setting (from no flaps) reduces the take-off distance quite significantly as the aircraft can lift-off at a lower speed, reducing the Take-Off Run
learning.explanation: Note: The feedback has been a bit contradictory for this question, and it seems very new to the EASA database. Please let us know if you see this question in the exam, and anything you can remember about it. Thank you! The effect of flaps on Take-off Distance (TOD) is as follows: Initially, increasing flap setting (from no flaps) reduces the take-off distance quite significantly as the aircraft can lift-off at a lower speed, reducing the Take-Off Run. The higher the flap setting though, the longer the distance from the lift-off point to reach the screen height, due to more drag. At a certain point though, the extra drag of high flap settings becomes a problem, as the aircraft will require a little more distance to accelerate and much more distance to reach the screen height. This extra distance eventually outweighs the small reduction in lift-off speeds when using high flap settings. The trick with this question is to note that there will be a peak flap setting that provides the minimum TOD, and the manufacturer is likely to make this the maximum allowed flap setting for take-off (if not even a lower flap setting). There is effectively no reason to ever need to take-off with flaps above this setting, and single engine climb gradient would likely be much more limiting by this point anyway. Therefore, it is our opinion that the correct answer is "Decreases, because the effect on lift-off speed is more significant than the extra drag created." Remember, the examiner is asking about a take-off with the maximum allowed take-off flap setting, not full flaps. It is possible the examiner may be actually asking about very high flap settings here, in which case, the answer will change to one that states that the distance increases as the extra drag outweighs the lower lift-off speed, but for now, we think that is not the purpose of this question, and if so, would require an appeal due to incorrect wording.

Upon landing, ground effect can give the effect of floating. The stall speed may be temporarily reduced due to ground effect. Ground effect is effective from the ground to approximately half the aircraft’s wingspan above ground. The effect is caused by the ground interrupting the wingtip vortices, decreasing the downwash angle. Below the airfoil, a higher pressure than if an airfoil travels at higher altitude is created, as the air below the airfoil is trapped in between the wing and the ground. key_points: Ailerons are the primary roll control surface on an aircraft, however, ailerons do present a few issues that must be overcome
Ailerons produce adverse yaw, which is where the down-going aileron increases the camber of the wing, and acts similar to a flap, increasing lift, as it is supposed to, but also increasing drag

learning.explanation: Ailerons are the primary roll control surface on an aircraft, however, ailerons do present a few issues that must be overcome. Ailerons produce adverse yaw, which is where the down-going aileron increases the camber of the wing, and acts similar to a flap, increasing lift, as it is supposed to, but also increasing drag. The up-going aileron reduces the wing camber, reducing drag. This causes an unwanted yaw towards the upward-going wing during a bank. Ailerons can also be affected by the twisting of a wing at high speeds, in an effect known as high speed aileron reversal. Adverse yaw from ailerons can be counteracted in a fe different ways: Roll spoilers. Frise ailerons. Differential ailerons. Roll spoilers are the subject of this question. Spoilers are aerodynamic devices that stick out of the top of a wing, giving a loss of lift similar to an up-going aileron and an increased drag similar to a split flap. They are used on almost all modern commercial jets. When spoilers are used as "roll spoilers", they are a primary flight control. They assist or replace the ailerons on the down-going wing by increasing drag and reducing lift. They use this increased drag to even out the drag of the down-going ailerons on the opposite wing, reducing or removing adverse aileron yaw.

learning.explanation: INDUCED DRAG Whenever a wing produces lift, concentrated vortices form at the wing tips. The vortices are strongest at the wing tips and become progressively weaker toward the centre-line of the aircraft. It is the production of lift itself which reduces the magnitude of the lift force being generated. To replace the lift lost by the increased downwash, the aircraft must be flown at a higher angle of attack. This increases drag. This extra drag is called induced drag. The stronger the vortices, the greater the induced drag. Wing tip modifications reduce the leakage of airflow around the wing tip and limit the size of the vortex. WINGLETS These are small vertical aerofoils which form part of the wing tip. Shaped and angled to the induced airflow, they generate a small forward force. This updraft turns into a downdraft behind the wing, creating a vortex. The higher the pressure difference between the top and bottom of the wing, the stronger the vortices. key_points: First of all, we can logically say that when an object is travelling through the air, water will strike the object on the front side
In our case this means that water or humidity will strike the leading edge of the wing and form into ice is conditions allow for the formation
Therefore when flying ice usually forms at the leading edge, however when on the ground ice usually forms on the top of the wings
learning.explanation: First of all, we can logically say that when an object is travelling through the air, water will strike the object on the front side. In our case this means that water or humidity will strike the leading edge of the wing and form into ice is conditions allow for the formation. Therefore when flying ice usually forms at the leading edge, however when on the ground ice usually forms on the top of the wings. Next, where does ice form on the leading edge specifically. The point where the airflow hits exactly 90 degrees on the surface is called the stagnation point. This is where water is most likely to stick to the wing and create ice. Water at the stagnation point will not be blown over the wing or under the wing because the air pushes on it at a 90 degree angle. That’s why ice always forms first at the stagnation point, then it usually spreads over the leading edge.

key_points: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together
Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air
It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag
learning.explanation: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together. Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air. It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag. Form drag arises from the shape of the object. The more streamlined the object, the less form drag is present. Shape and size are most important in the amount of form drag resulting. Form drag increases with increasing velocity, making it very important for high speed aircraft. Skin friction drag is caused by the friction of the fluid (in case of aircraft this fluid is the atmosphere) against the skin of the object moving through it. It is directly related to the surface area in contact with the fluid. Skin friction increases with the square of the velocity. Induced drag is caused when an object redirects the airflow. A wing produces lift by creating a pressure difference. This pressure difference is caused by the shape of the airfoil, causing the airflow on top to accelerate, creating a low pressure on top of the wing and high pressure below the wing. This pressure difference naturally wants to restore towards a uniform pressure, which creates vortices around the wingtip. These vortices are deflected downwards, this phenomenon is also called downwash. The induced drag decreases with airspeed. In the image we can see that the two vectors (induced and parasite drag) create a resulting vector, the total drag. Where the induced and parasite drag vectors collide, we have the minimum drag speed (VMD); the speed where the total drag is the lowest. This leads us to understand that during an acceleration from a total stand still, the total drag first decreases up until the minimum drag speed and then starts increasing again.

learning.explanation: The centre of pressure is the point on the chord line of an aerofoil (a line through the aerofoil joining the leading edge and the trailing edge), where all the aerodynamic forces are concentrated. content.question: A positively cambered aerofoil will generate:

options.A: zero lift at a positive angle of attack.
options.B: zero lift at zero angle of attack.
options.C: zero lift at a negative angle of attack.
options.D: lift at all angles of attack.

key_points: Camber is the asymmetry between two acting surfaces on an airfoil
For an aircraft, this is the top and the bottom of the wing
Positive camber means that a wing is thicker on the top end of the wing, than on the bottom if looked at from the chord
learning.explanation: Camber is the asymmetry between two acting surfaces on an airfoil. For an aircraft, this is the top and the bottom of the wing. Positive camber means that a wing is thicker on the top end of the wing, than on the bottom if looked at from the chord. In case of positive camber, a wing will generate lift with airspeed, as the air on top of the airfoil will get accelerated more than on the bottom, creating a low pressure on the top and high pressure at the bottom. This is “pushing” the wing up into the air as the pressure difference wants to restore itself to 0 difference. In case of negative camber, the exact opposite happens and the lift coefficient for a certain speed is lower than for a positively cambered wing. A completely symmetrical airfoil will intersect the vertical axis of the graph at the origin (0). A positively cambered airfoil will generate more lift at the same speed (and therefore has a higher CL) than a symmetrical airfoil and therefore intersects the vertical axis above the origin (and generates 0 lift at a negative angle of attack). A negatively cambered airfoil will generate less lift at the same speed (which translates into a lower CL at a certain speed) and therefore intersects the vertical axis below the origin. The camber of an airfoil can be increased with the use of flaps. The end of the wing reaches out and/or downwards, changing the side profile of the wing and moving the CP aft, resulting in a nose down pitching moment. This generates a higher value of CL at the same Angle of Attack. Therefore if flaps are being retracted, the Angle of Attack should be increased.

learning.explanation: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together. It acts in the direction of the relative wind. Lift is perpendicular to the relative wind. Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air. It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag. Form drag arises from the shape of the object. The more streamlined the object, the less form drag is present. Shape and size are most important in the amount of form drag resulting. Form drag increases with increasing velocity, making it very important for high speed aircraft. Skin friction drag is caused by the friction of the fluid (in case of aircraft this fluid is the atmosphere) against the skin of the object moving through it. It is directly related to the surface area in contact with the fluid. Skin friction increases with the square of the velocity. Induced drag is caused when an object redirects the airflow. A wing produces lift by creating a pressure difference. This pressure difference is caused by the shape of the airfoil, causing the airflow on top to accelerate, creating a low pressure on top of the wing and high pressure below the wing. This pressure difference naturally wants to restore towards a uniform pressure, which creates vortices around the wingtip. These vortices are deflected downwards, this phenomenon is also called downwash. The induced drag decreases with airspeed (with a rate of 1/V²) and increases with angle of attack and increasing weight. In the image we can see that the two vectors (induced and parasite drag) create a resulting vector, the total drag. Where the induced and parasite drag vectors collide, we have the minimum drag speed (VMD); the speed where the total drag is the lowest. This leads us to understand that during an acceleration from a total stand still, the total drag first decreases up until the minimum drag speed and then starts increasing again. If we add flaps to the clean configuration, CL will increase, but so will the drag. This degrades glide performance. The rate of descent will increase and glide range will decrease.

To give favourable stall characteristics, a tapered wing must be modified using one or more of the following: Geometric twist (washout), a decrease in incidence from root to tip
learning.explanation: In some wing designs, separation tends to occur first in the region of the tip, reducing lift in those areas. If an actual wing were allowed to stall in this way, stalling would give aileron buffet and perhaps violent wing drop. To give favourable stall characteristics, a tapered wing must be modified using one or more of the following: Geometric twist (washout), a decrease in incidence from root to tip. This decreases the angle of attack at the tip, and the root will tend to stall first. The aerofoil section may be varied throughout the span such that sections with greater thickness and camber are located near the tip. The higher CLMAX of such sections delays stall so that the root will tend to stall first.

content.question: Which of the following causes an increase in downwash behind a wing?

options.A: Increased dynamic pressure.
options.B: Stronger wingtip vortices.
options.C: The aeroplane entering ground effect.
options.D: Decreased lift.

key_points: DOWNWASH Downwash is the effect of a wing changing the local relative airflow
It is also the term for the air being forced downwards behind a wing
The terms are very closely linked, and often refer to the exact same thing, but there are subtle differences to how we view it in different contexts as part of the syllabus
learning.explanation: DOWNWASH Downwash is the effect of a wing changing the local relative airflow. It is also the term for the air being forced downwards behind a wing. The terms are very closely linked, and often refer to the exact same thing, but there are subtle differences to how we view it in different contexts as part of the syllabus. Evaluating all possible meanings, the only correct answer is "stronger wingtip vortices". INDUCED DRAG Whenever a wing produces lift, some air tries to "cheat" the wing and travel around the wingtip, creating wingtip vortices that affect the lift of the rest of the wing. The vortices are strongest at the wing tips and become progressively weaker toward the centre-line of the aircraft. These vortices create upwash in front of the wing and downwash behind the wing, effectively changing the local relative airflow, and therefore changing the effective angle of attack of the wing. This produces inefficiencies and means the wing's lift is produced at an angle, and some of the lift turns into drag, called induced drag. The stronger the vortices, the greater the induced drag. The stronger the wingtip vortices, the greater the downwash behind the wing. As part of producing a lifting force on the aircraft, a wing must force air to go downwards, to satisfy Newton's 2nd law of motion (equal and opposite reactions). This is referred to as downwash also, and means that the air flowing away from a wing is pointing slightly downwards, but it arrived at the wing perfectly horizontal, for instance. The amount of "downwash" is directly proportional to the lift produced, and therefore: Decreased lift produces less downwash. Increased dynamic pressure means higher airspeed, but has no effect on the magnitude of lift, and therefore downwash, and will actually decrease the angle of the downwash, due to more air flowing over the wing for the same lift force. This is assuming the same lift force, which we see as much more realistic than assuming a constant angle of attack or lift coefficient, etc., for these questions. Entering ground effect reduces the effect of wingtip vortices, making the wing more efficient, due to the reduced downwash (as the air cannot flow down as much due to the ground in the way).

key_points: Whenever a wing produces lift, concentrated vortices form at the wing tips
The vortices are strongest at the wing tips and become progressively weaker toward the centerline of the aircraft
The vortices induce downwash to the airflow behind the wing, causing the lift vector to tilt rearward
learning.explanation: Whenever a wing produces lift, concentrated vortices form at the wing tips. The vortices are strongest at the wing tips and become progressively weaker toward the centerline of the aircraft. The vortices induce downwash to the airflow behind the wing, causing the lift vector to tilt rearward. The horizontal component of lift opposes the forward flight of the aircraft and is known as induced drag. The larger the vortex, the greater the induced downwash, and the greater the induced drag. The induced drag can be defined by: CDI= CL2 / π*AR Where, CDI – Induced Drag Coefficient CL2 – Lift Coefficient squared AR – Aspect Ratio Increasing the angle of attack increases CL. From the formula we can deduct that Induced drag is directly proportional to CL squared. So, decreasing the angle of attack decreases CL, which decreases Induced drag. Therefore, statement 1 is correct. From the formula we can deduct that Induced drag is inversely proportional to Aspect Ratio. So, as the Aspect Ration increases, the Induced Drag decreases. Therefore, statement 2 is incorrect.

content.question: As an aeroplane slows down during the approach, the wing tip vortices and downwash will vary in intensity. How does this affect the induced angle of attack? Induced angle of attack will...

options.A: decrease, especially near the wing tip.
options.B: increase, especially at the leading edge.
options.C: increase, especially near the wing tip.
options.D: decrease, especially at the leading edge.

key_points: The airflow around an aerofoil section sets up a pressure differential between the upper and lower surfaces
The lower surface of a wing is normally at a pressure above atmospheric, whilst the upper surface is at a pressure below atmospheric
Beyond the wing tips the air is nominally at atmospheric pressure
learning.explanation: The airflow around an aerofoil section sets up a pressure differential between the upper and lower surfaces. The lower surface of a wing is normally at a pressure above atmospheric, whilst the upper surface is at a pressure below atmospheric. Beyond the wing tips the air is nominally at atmospheric pressure. This causes a spanwise flow of air outward away from the fuselage on the lower surface and an inward flow toward the fuselage on the upper surface. At the trailing edge of the wing, where the two flows meet, a twisting motion is imparted to the air and a series of vortices form. These are trailing edge vortices. The effect of these vortices is to create more down wash behind the wing than up wash in front of the wing. This results in the effective air flow (EAF) being inclined to the relative air flow (RAF) by an angle called the induced angle of attack (αi). Because of this local increase in induced angle of attack, the overall lift generated by a wing will be below the value that would be generated if there were no spanwise pressure differential. It is the production of lift itself which reduces the magnitude of the lift force being generated. To replace the lift lost by the increased downwash, the aircraft must be flown at a higher angle of attack. This increases drag. This extra drag is called induced drag. The stronger the vortices, the greater the induced drag. Induced drag increases with decreasing speed (for a constant lift force). This is because, as speed decreases, the downwash caused by the tip vortices becomes more significant, the rearward inclination of the lift is bigger, and therefore induced drag is higher.

Since the slats have not extended on the left wing, unlike the right wing, the left wing is not benefitting from a greater critical angle of attack. When the trailing edge flaps are extended, critical angle of attack is decreased. Consequently, the wings are now closer to their critical AOA. A decreased speed asks for a greater angle of attack. The left wing (slats retracted) may stall when the flaps are extended.

Given a constant load factor, which of these statements is correct about the variation of induced drag with changes of speed and mass are correct or incorrect?
1. When speed increases, induced drag decreases.
2. When mass increases, induced drag decreases.

options.A: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.
options.B: 1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.
options.C: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.D: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.

key_points: Induced drag is created as a by product of lift
The pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing creates a upwash around the tip of the wing that turns into a downwash behind the wing
This is known as a vortex, which creates a rearward force known as induced drag
learning.explanation: Induced drag is created as a by product of lift. The pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing creates a upwash around the tip of the wing that turns into a downwash behind the wing. This is known as a vortex, which creates a rearward force known as induced drag. This question is asking for the effect of: Speed: The induced drag is inversely proportional to the speed. Therefore, induced drag increases as the speed decreases, and, induced drag decreases and the speed increases. This is because, to maintain lift constant, as the velocity decreases, the coefficient of lift will have to be increased. At higher coefficients of lift, the pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing will be greater and therefore produce stronger vortices = stronger induced drag. (and vice versa) Changing mass: Induced drag is proportional to the mass. Therefore, induced drag increases with increasing aeroplane mass, and, induced drag decreases with decreasing aeroplane mass. This is because, as the aircraft get heavier, the lift that the wings will have to produce increases. To achieve that, the coefficient of lift will have to increase, meaning a higher AoA, which creates stronger vortices. (and vice versa) Summary: Higher AR = Lower induced drag Higher AoA = higher induced drag Higher weight = higher AoA = higher induced drag Higher speed = lower AoA = lower induced drag Winglets = lower induced drag.

content.question:
Which of these statements about a steady subsonic flow are correct or incorrect?
1. The static pressure does not change as the streamlines diverge.
2. The velocity decreases as the streamlines diverge.

options.A: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.B: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.C: 1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.
options.D: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.

key_points: To understand the venturi effect, we must first introduce two conditions: The conservation of mass (Continuity Equation) and the Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem)
Conservation of Mass (Continuity Equation) The mass of air entering the pipe, in each unit of time, equals the mass of air leaving the pipe, in the same unit of time
The mass flow through the pipe must remain constant
learning.explanation: To understand the venturi effect, we must first introduce two conditions: The conservation of mass (Continuity Equation) and the Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem). Conservation of Mass (Continuity Equation) The mass of air entering the pipe, in each unit of time, equals the mass of air leaving the pipe, in the same unit of time. The mass flow through the pipe must remain constant. The mass air flow 'm' is the product of the density, the area and the velocity: m = ρ * A * V Continuity equation: m1 = m2 = m3 = ρ1 * A1 * V1 = ρ2 * A2 * V2 = ρ3 * A3 * V3 = constant The continuity equation explains the relationship between velocity and cross-sectional area: The speed is inversely proportional to the cross-sectional area. Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem) The total energy of an airstream comes in two forms: potential energy (static pressure) and kinetic energy (dynamic pressure). The total pressure of the airstream is the sum of the static pressure and the dynamic pressure and must remain constant, according to the law of conservation of energy. Thus, an increase in one form of pressure, must result in a decrease in the other. Dynamic pressure (q) is expressed by: q = 1 / 2 * ρ * V2 Assuming the total pressure to be constant, the static pressure and the dynamic pressure vary inversely: If one increases the other decreases and vice-versa. As an airfoil (wing) moves through the air, varying changes in velocity occur on its surfaces. Air particles move around it in specific trajectories. These trajectories are called streamlines. Diverging streamlines mean a decrease in airspeed. Converging streamlines imply an increase in airspeed. In Conclusion: With an increase in section area (from station 2 to station 3), flow speed decreases, decreasing dynamic pressure (streamlines diverge). If dynamic pressure decreases, static pressure increases. Statement 1 is therefore incorrect. With an increase in section area (from station 2 to station 3), flow speed decreases, decreasing dynamic pressure (streamlines diverge). Statement 2 is therefore correct.

content.question: An aeroplane in straight and level flight at a speed of 1.1 VS and a lift coefficient (CL) of 1.22 accelerates to a speed of 1.8 VS. What is the new CL?

key_points: Lift can be calculated as follows: L= CL × ½ rho × V2 × S Where: CL is lift coefficient (without dimension) rho is density [kg/m3] V is velocity, or TAS [m/s] S is the wing's surface area [m2] L is lift [N] ⇒ If the aircraft continues in straight and level flight, then the lift value remains the same
The density and wing surface area are remaining the same also
This means the only changing figures are CL and V, so this is just a proportional change question
learning.explanation: Lift can be calculated as follows: L= CL × ½ rho × V2 × S Where: CL is lift coefficient (without dimension) rho is density [kg/m3] V is velocity, or TAS [m/s] S is the wing's surface area [m2] L is lift [N] ⇒ If the aircraft continues in straight and level flight, then the lift value remains the same. The density and wing surface area are remaining the same also. This means the only changing figures are CL and V, so this is just a proportional change question. The lift coefficient multiplied by the velocity2 must equal the same value for all speeds in this scenario, so we can say: Old CL x Old V2 = New CL x New V2 New CL = Old CL x (Old V2 / New V2) New CL = Old CL x (Old V / New V)2 So therefore, the New CL is 1.22 x (1.1/1.8)2 = 0.456 As a gross error check, we have increased speed so therefore the coefficient of lift to keep the Lift force constant has decreased, which makes sense. In words, the coefficient of lift is inversely proportional to the square of the change in speed (True Air Speed).

content.question: How would the TODR (take-off distance required) for a fixed wing aircraft vary with increasing flap settings (from retracted to full flaps)?

options.A: It would decrease.
options.B: It would increase.
options.C: It would decrease and then increase.
options.D: It would increase and then decrease.

key_points: Learning Objective 081
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 081.01.09.01.09: Explain the effects of flap-setting errors, such as mis-selection and premature/late extension or retraction of flaps, on: take-off and landing distance and speeds; climb and descent performance; stall buffet margins. Flaps increase the camber (and sometimes the area) of the wing, which increases the amount of lift that can be produced by the wing, for the same IAS (indicated airspeed). They also increase the drag of the wing, by more than they increase lift. This means that the aircraft will always fly more efficiently (better L/D ratio) without flaps, hence why they are not used in the cruise, or the climb, when possible. Flaps are primarily used for take-off and landing. For take-off, we can rotate at a lower speed, using less runway, and maintain a lower flying speed on the initial climb out. For landing, we can approach at a slower speed (with a higher approach angle if necessary, due to the extra drag), and therefore land in a shorter distance. For take-off, using flaps is a trade-off between runway length and climb requirements. Flaps are bad for climbing, as they produce more drag, but they will get us off the runway earlier. Therefore, if there is a long runway and high obstacles around, lower (or no) flaps should be used, whereas a short field take-off with few obstacles should use higher flap settings. If there is a short field with obstacles, run the performance calculations carefully for both, and use whichever is better. In terms of this question, the take-off distance will obviously reduce from no flaps (clean) to some flaps, due to the lower distance to rotation, but will begin to increase again towards full flaps, as the aircraft have so much drag that even if it does leave the ground early, it will struggle to climb to the screen height. Many aircraft would not be able to sustain a climb at all with full flaps set, and the final stage of flaps often produces little extra lift than the last stage, but produces lots more drag.

Total Drag is sub-divided into two main types: INDUCED DRAG - the result of lift generation. PARASITE DRAG - independent of lift generation. key_points: Vortex generators, are rows of small, thin aerofoil shaped blades which project vertically (about 2
5 cm) into the airstream

The principle of operation of vortex generators is that they create small vortices that cause the faster moving air above the boundary layer to be deflected from the top of the boundary layer to the slower moving air near the aerofoil surface
learning.explanation: Vortex generators, are rows of small, thin aerofoil shaped blades which project vertically (about 2.5 cm) into the airstream. The principle of operation of vortex generators is that they create small vortices that cause the faster moving air above the boundary layer to be deflected from the top of the boundary layer to the slower moving air near the aerofoil surface. This transfers momentum and re-energises the lower layer of the boundary air, delaying the separation point to further aft along the aerofoil surface. Vortex generators are also frequently used on a swept wing to delay tip stall and improve the stall characteristics. Vortex generators are usually located on the upper wing surface, particularly ahead of control surfaces, but may be used anywhere where separation is causing high drag or reduced control effectiveness. For aeroplanes travelling at high subsonic or transonic speeds, vortex generators weaken the shockwave and decrease shock drag but have no diminishing effect on wing-tip vortices. Nevertheless, the vortices produced by the vortex generators diminish shock buffet and are beneficial to the aeroplane’s overall performance

learning.explanation: Camber is the asymmetry between two acting surfaces on an airfoil. For an aircraft, this is the top and the bottom of the wing. Positive camber means that a wing is thicker on the top end of the wing, than on the bottom if looked at from the chord. In case of positive camber, a wing will generate lift with airspeed, as the air on top of the airfoil will get accelerated more than on the bottom, creating a low pressure on the top and high pressure at the bottom. This is “pushing” the wing up into the air as the pressure difference wants to restore itself to 0 difference. In case of negative camber, the exact opposite happens and the lift coefficient for a certain speed is lower than for a positively cambered wing. A completely symmetrical airfoil will intersect the vertical axis of the graph at the origin (0). A positively cambered airfoil will generate more lift at the same speed (and therefore has a higher CL) than a symmetrical airfoil and therefore intersects the vertical axis above the origin. A negatively cambered airfoil will generate less lift at the same speed (which translates into a lower CL at a certain speed) and therefore intersects the vertical axis below the origin.
